results.title: Following Falsehoods: A Reporter’s Approach on QAnon
results.abstract: Kevin Roose, a Times tech columnist, has watched the baseless conspiracy theory grow from fringe internet subculture to mass movement, carefully calibrating his coverage along the way.

multimedia.caption: Attendees at a QAnon rally in Washington, D.C., in September. The movement and its falsehoods keep growing.

results.title: In ‘The Field’ Podcast, Voters Are the Main Characters
results.abstract: After a pandemic-induced hiatus, the show has returned, with a focus on the voices of Americans throughout the country as they grapple with the weightiest questions of the November election.

multimedia.caption: The audio producer Jessica Cheung, left, with the politics reporter Astead W. Herndon, center, in North Andover, Mass. They interviewed Lyn Licciardello, right, a supporter of Elizabeth Warren, in March for an episode of “The Field” after Ms. Warren dropped out of the Democratic presidential primary race.

The audio producer Jessica Cheung, left, with the politics reporter Astead W. Herndon, center, in North Andover, Mass. They interviewed Lyn Licciardello, right, a supporter of Elizabeth Warren, in March for an episode of “The Field” after Ms. Warren dropped out of the Democratic presidential primary race.

results.title: What’s It Like to Take the SAT in a Pandemic? To Find Out, I Took the Exam Myself
results.abstract: Did I a) ace it; b) better understand students’ experiences; c) question my own rational judgment for going through this again? Hint: It’s not all of the above.

multimedia.caption: The Times reporter Emma Goldberg outside the test site in Sleepy Hollow, N.Y. Her scores won’t matter — but don’t ask her to reveal them.

results.title: We Want to Hear From You
results.abstract: Do you have a story idea, a question for our newsroom or feedback on our coverage? Let us know.

results.abstract: We would like to hear how employees and employers are handling a return to their offices, even as others continue working from home.

results.title: Times Readers Reflect on Ruth Bader Ginsburg
results.abstract: ‘She showed me that one can be soft-spoken, yet substantial.’

results.title: Capturing the Faces of Climate Migration
results.abstract: A Times Magazine series examines how climate change will force millions worldwide to move. Recently, Meridith Kohut photographed people on the front lines of this shift. In America.

multimedia.caption: Consuelo Sandoval (left) and her husband, Roberto González, rush to evacuate their home in Sonoma County, Calif., after getting notified of approaching wildfires.

results.title: Has the Mail Really Slowed? We Wanted to Find Out
results.abstract: To track the speed of delivery across the country, The Upshot thought about a pen pal network before partnering with a company that collects the data.
results.byline: By Emily Badger and Quoctrung Bui

results.title: What I Saw When Australia Burned
results.abstract: At one point, the wildfires that country experienced seemed to fade from our memory. Not anymore. And what I witnessed there has shaped my thoughts on what’s raging here.

multimedia.caption: Amir Kamrani (left), assistant cameraman, and Victor Suarez, director of photography, survey damage in South Nowra, Australia, for an episode of “The New York Times Presents.”

results.title: Disasters on Two Coasts: How to Help
results.abstract: With fires on the West Coast and floods on the Gulf Coast, relief organizations are providing meals and shelter to devastated communities. If you want to give aid, here are some research pointers.
results.byline: By Concepción de León and Christine Hauser

results.title: How My 2-Year-Old Planted a Coronavirus Story Idea
results.abstract: After another child at my son’s day care tested positive, I ran into obstacle after obstacle trying to get him a test. I quickly learned I wasn’t alone among concerned parents of young children.

results.title: Off the Shore, Finding Sharks and Freedom
results.abstract: Reporting on a unique group of fishermen was an adventure. Getting on the water myself was otherworldly.

results.title: Share Your Memories of Big Basin Redwoods State Park
results.abstract: Though the forest is expected to survive, nearly all the structures in California’s oldest state park have burned down. Tell us what you loved most about the place.

multimedia.caption: Don’t mistake that scowl for any displeasure with Big Basin. Most likely it had to do with the writer’s own, curious choice of forest attire.

results.title: Helping Parents Hold the Line
results.abstract: Whether it’s covering issues about safety, schooling or burnout, the members of the Parenting desk are working during this “new reality” to support caregivers on all fronts.

multimedia.caption: Farah Miller’s 5-year-old daughter, Bergen, was not pleased about the closed-door policy in her mom’s home office recently. Like millions of caregivers nationwide, Parenting desk staff members are juggling work, home and school issues.
